description.narrative: National REDD+ strategy drafted

comment.narrative: 1.Environment Policy exists 2. National Climate Response Strategy finalised 3. Forest Policy and Act do not recognise carbon sequestration as a forest product
1. Finalization of the REDD strategy 2. Publishing of the REDD+ strategy 3. Drafting concept note for targeted support 4. conduct terminal evaluation

1. REDD+ strategy.The REDD strategy acknowledges the importance of forests achievement of a low carbon and green economy. The reduction in deforestation and forest degradation is one of the greatest challenges to sustainable development and reduction of emissions. The REDD+ strategy aims at assisting the country to reduce emissions in an effective, efficient, transparent and accountable way, and anchored on fairness and inclusiveness.
The REDD+ strategy has been developed on the basis of an integrated natural resources management perspective and landscape level. It has also been informed by an analysis of the practical issues and key sectors of the economy that contribute to deforestation and forest degradation as well as the draft national climate change response strategy.
2. targeted support proposal- The targeted support aims to complete the safeguard information system, Monitoring reporting and verification and development of the REDD+ investment plan that will catalyze accessing funds to implement various components of the strategy 3. Terminal evaluation to be conducted in 2016

1. Benefit sharing study on natural resources completed. 2. Ministry of Tourism and Arts and Zambia Wildlife Authority have reviewed the wildlife policy taking into account new developments and innovations including benefit sharing mechanisms.

Status as at September 30: 1. The Benefit Sharing Study was completed in July. The study highlights the following recommendations that have been integrated into the draft revised policy: i) Tenure and transfer of tenure and the need for a clear policy for access to land; ii) the possibility of Public Private Partnerships; iii) Revision to the institutional arrangements for management of wildlife resources and the benefit sharing framework. 2. The draft Revised Wildlife Policy developed and being reviewed by stakeholders in all the provinces. The revised policy has introduced the following new/ innovative issues; i) Joint management of wildlife resources on public land with Forestry Department and conservation of wildlife in ‘open areas’ to be based on a cooperative framework with local communities and private landholders willing to adopt wildlife land use option of establishing appropriate private wildlife estate or community based wildlife management area ii) CBNRM to enable ownership and control of natural resources by users by devolving management of natural resources and assign responsibilities and benefits, ownership and user rights to communities. Local tenure arrangements to be recognized and rights of access to natural resources to be formalised and safeguarded iii) Reclassification of Protected Areas to include additional protected area categories known as Game Reserves, Nature Parks and Geoparks and upgrading the conservation status of selected GMAs and forest reserves to improve management effectiveness; iv) proposal to review the Zambia Wildlife Act No. 12 of 1998 to provide for cross sectoral linkages required to effectively coordinate wildlife matters with other sector institutions of Government; v) The explicit legal role of the Village Action Groups as entry points for inter-agency collaboration and extension in natural resource management, serving as a direct links to households; vi) The implementation of the National Decentralisation Policy, by

comment.narrative: Absence of integrated public service Capacity Development Plan and a roll out strategy
Draft strategy for the standardization of policy planning, implementation and monitoring developed, taking into consideration the gap analysis and mapping completed in 2014.

Strategy has been completed and has been going analysis by Cabinet Office to identify priority areas for implementation. This process considered the main three components of the report: (i) Gap Analysis (ii) Proposed standardised framework for coordination, and (iii) Implementation arrangements. The workshop identified two options (areas), namely (i) Enhancing the Capacity of Cabinet Office, and (ii) Establishing a new coordinating agency. A working group was appointed to deliberate further on the two options and prepare a detailed position paper for submission to Cabinet Office.

i) Implement set of priority areas under the Standardised Performance Management Framework ii) Finalise development of Capacity Development Plan for Cabinet Office and the 5 selected ministries ii) Revise Cabinet Office manuals to align them to the amended constitution iii) Conduct capacity building programme for senior government officials

• New measures to enhance Results Based Management adopted and President directed Ministries, Provinces and Spending Agencies to start submitting quarterly reports to Cabinet on their performance. • 2016 Post-Election Orientation workshop for Cabinet and Provincial Ministers conducted. • Gaps in coordination of Government business identified and whole of Government approach adopted. Capacity Development Plan developed. • Government adopted use of a scorecard and implementation. Permanent Secretaries from each Ministry and Province trained and certified in International Balanced Scorecard. The aim is to link performance objectives to national planning, interventions and targets for better monitoring and government-wide coordination. • Training on Effective Communication of Government Business for Permanent Secretaries and Senior Officials conducted. • Revision and alignment of cabinet documents to the amended constitution conducted. These include: Guide to Preparing National Policy Documents and Cabinet Memoranda, Cabinet Handbook, Secretariat Manual for Servicing Cabinet and Cabinet Committees, and the Rules and Procedures.

title.narrative: Support to the Human Rights Co

description.narrative: Domestication of International Instruments
independent political entity
Human rights affairs
Baseline Survey on Zambia’s Ratification and Domestication of International HR Instruments

comment.narrative: Baseline survey does not exist

(i) Draft Bill on the Criminalisation of Torture developed. (ii) Public Engagement and Advocacy Strategy on Criminalisation of Torture developed. (iii) HRC Education Manual (iv) HRC Communication Strategy developed. (v) Conduct baseline survey on Zambia’s Ratification and Domestication of International HR Instruments

(i) A high level symposium was held in March with a resolution to expedite the criminalization of torture. Countrywide consultative workshops have been jointly held by the Human Rights Commission and the Zambia Law Development Commission to get views on criminalizing torture. (ii) Public Engagement and Advocacy Strategy on Criminalisation of Torture has been developed and operationalized. The campaign brought together a number of stakeholders including government, law enforcement agencies, civil society, private sector, the church, and parliamentarians, all acknowledging that torture exists in Zambia and there is need to criminalise the scourge. Parliamentary Committee on Legal Affairs, Governance, Human Rights, Gender Matters and Child Affairs conducted its meetings and public hearings on ‘Causes and Extent of Torture in Zambia’. The committee submitted its report to the National Assembly with recommendations which included the following; (i) the country fully domesticates the UNCAT through provisions clearly defining torture and specifically stating acts constituting torture both in the Constitution and subsequently in the relevant statues; (ii) the Government of Zambia to demonstrate commitment to the elimination of torture by lifting the reservation and recognising the competence of the Committee against Torture; and (iii) the Government should urgently strengthen the public sensitisation programmes being undertaken under the Human Rights Commission on what amounts to torture in order to empower the citizens to claim their rights. (iii) The Education Manual has been drafted and is being finalised. (iv) Communication strategy has been developed and HRC staff have undergone training in the use of the strategy for both internal and external communication. (v) Baseline survey to be conducted the following year.
i) Finalise drafting the Bill on Criminalising Torture ii) Strengthen the Capacity of Human Rights Commission iii) Produce the 2015 Annual State of Human Rights Report

• Draft Bill on Criminalising Torture has been developed and validated. To be submitted to Government. • HRC has maintained its A status rating for the institution. The institution attended compliance review in Geneva to assess compliance with Paris Principles by GANHRI (former ICC). • 7 HRC commissioners appointed and underwent orientation on their roles as commissioners • 2015 Annual State of Human Rights Report produced

1. 20 JCTR staff were trained in September in HRBA and RBM as well as going through Training of Trainers. A total of 150 Provincial Planning Units and key staff have been trained in HRBA and RBA in all the 10 provinces. Further all outreach teams in the six districts - Livingstone, Monze, Mongu, Kabwe, Ndola and Kasama have undergone training in HRBA and RBA.
2. Monitoring tools by Parliament/MPs on the implementation of international instruments have been developed. 21 MPs and 2 staff of the National Assembly were trained on the use of these tools.

i) Engage stakeholders to raise awareness on disability and persons with disability issues ii) Conduct an audit of public infrastructure on its responsiveness to disability issues. iii) Operationalise outreach groups to raise awareness on ESCR to both service providers and communities

i) Engagements on persons with disabilities and disability issues held in all the provincial capitals and teams have been established in each province to follow up on recommendations. A national symposium on persons with disabilities and disability issues was held on 7th December in Lusaka and various stakeholders including government, private sector, CSOs, Disability Persons Organisations and persons with disabilities attended. A number of commitments were made. ii) An audit/assessment of public infrastructure to ascertain their responsiveness to persons with disabilities has been undertaken and findings to be shared with government and other stakeholders. iii) Six outreach groups in Livingstone, Monze, Mongu, Kabwe, Ndola and Kasama have been established and are fully operational. They have created platform for duty bearers and communities to effectively engage each other in the provision and of accessing of services. Communities have become more aware of their ESCR and are service providers are responding favourably.

comment.narrative: Women Parliamentary Caucus does not exist 3 Portfolio Commitees undertook public hearings at constituency level Parliamentary reforms not undertaken
1. National Assembly of Zambia Strategic Plan finalised, launched and implemented. 2. National Assembly of Zambia Staff trained in Results Based Management.

1. The 2015-2019 Strategic Plan for the National Assembly was finalised, approved, and launched by the Hon Speaker in June, and implementation commenced immediately. Implementation of the Strategic Plan has led to the National Assembly better position itself in discharging its core functions. NAZ has strengthened its capacity by undertaking the following; (i) formation and capacity building of the Strategic Plan Implementation Committee; (ii) Development of the Strategic Plan Implementation Plan; and (iii) Development of the Monitoring and Evaluation Framework for the Strategic Plan (this framework includes performance management framework).
2. Capacity building for staff in Results Based Management was conducted in September and 35 key staff were trained.

i) Revise Parliament Standing Orders to align them to amended constitution ii) Conduct Post Election Orientation Seminar for new Members of Parliament iii) Revise the 2011 – 2015 National Assembly Communications Strategy and develop a new one. iv) Increase the participation of women in decision-making, in particular in parliament

i) Standing Orders have been revised and approved by National Assembly management. It is expected that the Committee on Parliamentary Reforms and Modernisation will formally approve the revised standing orders before parliament adjourns this December. A gap analysis was conducted and led to the engagement of a consultant to facilitate the review of the standing order. It was the preliminary phase required in order to allow for amending of the Standing Orders.
ii) National Assembly Communications Strategy for 2017 – 2021 developed.
iii) 2016 Post Election Orientation Seminar conducted for all the 156 elected and 8 nominated Members of Parliament to enhance their capacity in discharging their representative, legislative and oversight mandate.
iv) Increase in female MPs from 23 to 30, with 11 female MPs in Cabinet – highest in the history of Zambia. 2016 Post-Election Orientation Workshop for the Zambia Women Parliamentarians conducted

(i) Rules of court for adjudicating GBV cases developed. (ii) Technical assistance, equipment and materials to operationalize pilot fast track courts provided (iii) Guidelines for incorporating CEDAW into customary court systems and processes developed (iv) Training of traditional leaders and customary court judges on the guidelines undertaken

(i)The rules of court have been drafted and submitted to the ministry of Justice for signature. (ii)All equipment and vehicles for the fast track courts have been procured and installed (iii)The manual for training local and traditional court adjudicators on incorporation of CEDAW guidelines into Customary Court systems and processes has been developed and Printed out. (i) Zambia Police Sexual and Gender Based Violence crimes databse established (ii) Ten Village led GBV One Stop Centers established (iii) One GBV Shelter established in Kabwe to support the Fast Track Court (iv) 300 local and traditional court adjudicators trained.

(i) The Zambia Police Sexual and Gender Based Violence databse has been established and the crime reporting occurance book had been made electronic. (ii) Eleven Village led One Stop Centers were established in four provinces of Zambia namely; Eastern, Lusaka, Central and Western.This has resulted in 1,200 GBV cases that have been reported by the communities, in these villages, and addressed by the police. (iii) Works on establishing a GBV shelter in the Central Province of Zambia, where the Kabwe GBV Fast Track Court has commenced. (iv) 204 customary court adjudicators that included headwomen and headmen who preside over cases at village level, as well as local court magistrates and local court officers were trained in adjudicating GBV cases in conformity with CEDAW, so that customary court adjudicators desist from enforcing customary practices that exacerbate GBV .

comment.narrative:
1. The country has no MDG Acceleration Plan focusing on poverty and unemployment; 2011 MDG Progress Report for Zambia exists and will be updated to include current development trends; and 2011 Zambia Human Development Report exists and will be updated to show current HDI for Zambia.
2. National Accounts, Input-Output and Social Accounting Matrices does not include gender disaggregated data and environment accounting systems.
3. The country does not have a database of viable, bankable and affordable appraised public investment projects.

1) Conduct in-house training on Public Investment Project Appraisal System for the Ministry of Finance - Zambia 2) Finalize, launch and disseminate the Zambia Human Development Report 2014 which is now ZHDR 2015 3) Produce, launch and disseminate the MDG Comprehensive Review Report

1) The Final technical report and manual for Public Investment Project Appraisal System for the MOF was developed following the stakeholder validation workshop held on 16 January 2015. Training on Public Investment Project Appraisal System and Implementation Analysis was held from 12 to 16 October 2015.
2) The draft 2015 ZHDR was finalised and subjected to a stakeholder review meeting in October 2015. The Report is currently undergoing technical editing in readiness for printing.
3) Following Zambia's adoption of the Sustainable Development Goals, a Comprehensive Review of the MDGs was undertaken to provide insight on the country's progress on MDGs since 2000. A draft report was produced and subjected to stakeholder review.

1. 2015 Comprehensive MDG Progress Report is Produced 2. 2016 Zambia National Human Development Report is produced and disseminated in all 10 provinces 3. Guides and Standard Operating Procedures for the Project Appraisal System at the Ministry of Finance Developed 4. The Seventh National Development Plan which has mainstreamed SDGs is produced by the Ministry of Finance

1. The Draft 2015 Comprehensive MDG Progress Report has been produced and validated with broad stakeholder consultation through out the process. The report is being finalised (editing and layout) for printing and expected to the launched early in 2016.
2. The 2016 Zambia National Human Development Report with the theme " Industrialisation and Human Development: Poverty Reduction through Employment and Wealth Creation" was produced and launched on 10th May 2016 in Lusaka. It was also disseminated through stakeholder consultations health in five other provinces (Central, Copperbelt, North-Western, Eastern and Southern)
3. Guidelines and Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for the Project Appraisal System has now been moved to the Ministry of National Development Planning were developed and adopted.
4. UNDP held provincial consultation the Private Sector and Civil Society Organisations on SDGs. UNDP also supported the mainstreaming of SDGs through Co-Charing with the Ministry of National Development Planning, the Government and UN Technical Working group on the preparation of the Seventh National Development Plan. The SDG Prioritisation and mainstreaming workshop which was supposed to be held in 2016 with the support of the Regional Service centre will take place in January 2017.

Strategy implemented to to increase women's land ownership

comment.narrative:
Gender Inequality Index -0.627
Number of Laws revised to conform to CEDAW provisions - 0 % of newly allocated state land 20% % of women in decision making positions in civil service Permanent Secretary - 19% Director - 23% Deputy Director - 43%

(i) Gender Equality Bill finalized for adoption by Parliament. (ii) Strategy for increasing women's access and ownership of land developed. (iii) The 2016 Count her in Strategy developed and implemented

(i)The Gender equality Bill has been approved by Cabinet and has been passed by Parliament for Presidential ascent (ii)The assessment of women’s ownership of land was conducted. The Ministry of Lands has increased the threshold for land that is allocated to women from 30% to 40%. The strategy to address the administrative hindrances to women owning title is under development. (iii)The strategy was developed and the preparations for its implementation by the Non-Governmental Organisations Coordinating Committee (NGOCC) have commenced.

(i) Strategy for increasing women representation in politics implemented. (ii) Implementation plan for the gender provisions of the new Constitution developed (iii)Gender Responsive budgeting institutionalized in 7 line ministries (iv) 2014 Gender Status Report produced.

(i)The Count Her in Strategy aimed at having at least 50 percent representation of female candidates was implemented. One political party (PF) set a target of having women comprise 40% of its adopted candidates. After the August elections, more women MPs and Councillors were elected in 2016 than in 2011 (26 female MPs elected in 2016 against the 17 elected in 2011 and 127 women councilors elected in 2016 against the 85 elected in 2011). (ii) Consultations on the implementation plan for the gender provisions of the new Consitution commenced and the TORS for the Gender Equity and Equality Commission Structure were developed. (iii)15Line Ministries have operationalized gender responsive budgeting tools, 9 out of the 15 line ministries have gender-responsivee budgets; whilst 12 Line ministries are reflecting expenditures on gender. (iv) The 2014 Gender Status Report was produced. It is an update of the 2011 Baseline Report and is a reflection of the progress being made towards attaining gender equity and equality as measured by the indicators set out in the National Monitoring and Evaluation Plan 2010-2015. The report measures the progress in relation to the 2011 Baseline with regard to the causes, effects, impacts and possible mitigation measures in key areas including education, health, decision - making, skills and economic participation

1. Procurement of 28 Automatic Weather Stations finalized 2. Instruments for rehabilitation of manual stations procured and 39 manual stations rehabilitated 3. Zambia Meteorological Department Staff skills upgraded in weather fore casting and climatology -12 in diploma in weather forecasting and 4 Degree in Climatology. 4. 1. The procurement of 28 Automatic Weather Stations (AWSs) has been completed and the equipment was delivered to the Zambia Meteorological Department (ZMD). An Engineer from ADCON provided onsite training for ZMD Staff at one of the project sites in Gwembe and installed one AWS which is now operational. The remaining 27 AWSs will be installed in 2016.
2. Procurement of the instruments for rehabilitation of manual stations has been finalized and delivery will be expected in the first quarter of 2016.
3. Sponsorship of the 12 Zambia Meteorological Department staff to study Diploma in Weather Forecasting and 3 to study Degree in Climatology is underway. University/College fees and student allowances paid for for the current semester/term
4. Baseline Study has been completed and has provided information on the capacity development needs. The outputs of this study are the baseline survey results, revised project outputs and activities, an updated monitoring and evaluation plan, and a process report which will be useful for follow up activities.

1. 41 existing manual monitoring stations procured and rehabilitated 2.Review and and install appropriate telecommunication infrastructure to establish connectivity to all procured automatic weather stations to strengthen Zambia Meteorological Department's capacity to monitor and forecast climate information. 3. Procure and install equipment including hardware required for modern meteorological forecasting workstations 4. Conduct training for Weather Forecasters on MESSIR-COM (software that provides accurate weather predictions and issues warnings about severe weather conditions) to provide upper air monitoring ascent measurements

1. All 41 manual weather stations rehabilitated and capacity to monitor and forecast extreme weather events enhanced through the upgraded systems 2.Telecommunications infrastructure procured and installed and capacity to monitor and forecast weather information increased 3. Forecasting workstations upgraded with uninterrupted observation of climate and weather information 4.Technical capacity of ZMD developed though training to improve the production of standard and customized weather and climate forecasts

1.Procure and install 100 automatic rain gauges in selected priority districts including solar panels, batteries and general packet radio modems for data transmission. 2. Develop and establish an online climate map room for agriculture, water, energy, health and disaster risk reduction products and services with a link to Zambia Meteorological climate information web based system 3.Undertake a Socio-economic benefit analysis of climate information to the agriculture, water, energy, health and disaster risk reduction 4.Develop and establish an early warning computing systems, with dissemination/transmission system 5. Establish a publish a public-private partnership between an interested private sector entity and Zambia Meteorological Department. This will include establishment of SOPs and agreement to allow the private sector company to use the data generated by the meteorological observation network for the purpose of selling products

description.narrative: To strengthen the climate monitoring capabilities early warning systems and available information for responding to climate shocks and planning adaptation to climate change in Zambia

1 Capacity as per capacity assessment scorecard
2 Domestic finance committed to ZMD and DMMU to monitor and warn against extreme weather and climate change

comment.narrative:
1 Average capacity scorecard rating of 80 across men and women see Annex 5 of project document
2 Annual budget of US322680 allocated to ZMD and US614057 allocated to DMMU

1 Capacity scorecard rating is increased to an average of 171 for both men and women see Annex 5 of project document
2 20 increase in annual domestic finance allocated to ZMD and DMMU to monitor and warn against extreme weather and climate change

This development objective is ontrack There has been capacity enhancement in climate information generation packaging and dissemination since the project commenced
1 ZMDs capacity score has increased from 80 to 105 out of 171 This has been achieved through training of staff of the implementing entities Eight officers from the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock MAL who were managing weather stations without any formal training in meteorology have been trained in meteorological observation and interpretation and are therefore now able to interpret and simplify weather information for use by local farming communities Twentytwo officers from the Zambia Meteorological Department ZMD have undergone a refresher course in meteorological codes compiling of climate information and packaging of weather and climate information This has improved capacities for climate information production packaging and dissemination at district level Also twenty officers from ZMD were trained as enumerators for the CIEWS national baseline survey This enumeration course empowered the meteorological staff to engage with communities on the application of climate information This has contributed to the staff providing and interpreting weather information for use by local communities which they in turn are using to plan their livelihood activities such as farming and fishing Thirty ZMD staff have received training in software applications that will enable them to improve data management at the weather stations and they have also been provided with new highcapacity computer hardware Furthermore ZMD has benefited from two advisor missions during the period under review The first mission was by the CIRDA Chief Technical Advisor on Alternative Technologies who built ZMDs capacity in Early Warning System design The second mission was by the UNDP RSC Programme Specialist for Disaster Risk Reduction and Climate Change who collaborated with ZMD to assess the equipment and staffing requirements for data rescue
2 There has been a 50 increase in domestic finance allocated to ZMD for early warning systems in the period under review from a budget of 322680 USD in the baseline year This is due to advocacy by ZMD and the Disaster Management and Mitigation Unit DMMU on the importance of early warning systems to safeguard lives livelihoods property and infrastructure

1 100 of men
100 of women
2 At least the Seventh National Development Plan to incorporate the availability of climate information into planning for the five year period
3 Sectorspecific tailored climate information packages produced for agriculture aviation water health tourism construction road and rail transport and energy

This outcome is ontrack
1 At the start of the project there was minimal evidence of application of hydrological meteorological and environmental information by individual Zambians in their livelihood activities The CIEWS project has conducted awarenessraising activities in the three CIEWS pilot districts ten other climatevulnerable districts and the ten provincial capitals Preliminary results from a recent national survey conducted by the CIEWS project has revealed that approximately 30 of those surveyed in 30 districts across the country now apply weather and climate information in planning their livelihood activities particularly fishing and farming This information is disseminated to them through radio television print media and the internet The project has contributed to enhancing public information on climate change as well as enhanced capacity of ZMD for web management so that uptodate weather information is made available to the general public For further information see wwwzmdgovzm A CIEWS project brochure is also available on this website
2 The Seventh National Development Plan is under development and its theme will be inclusive green growth in recognition of the impacts of climate change Currently there is training for planners in all vulnerable key sectors on climate change mainstreaming and national adaptation planning
3 ZMD is providing more timely and accurate tailored information to the aviation sector daily flight forecasts and agricultural sector 10day crop weather bulletins available on ZMD website wwwzmdgovzm and distributed to farmers Tailored information for agriculture has contributed to the small scale farmers receiving appropriate information in good time to be used for planning For other sectors tailored information is provided on request This has been enabled through institutional strengthening by providing modern equipment and training

39 rehabilitated manual stations collecting data at the synoptic hours of GMT 06h00 09h00 12h00 15h00 18h00 and 00h00 and sending to ZMD daily

This outcome is ontrack
1 At the start of the project Zambia Meteorological Department had a network of 39 manual weather stations that were each missing some instruments and two automatic weather stations that had been vandalized The manual weather stations are to be rehabilitated in the second half of 2015 as the instruments are under procurement The target of 29 of districts having automatic weather stations has already been exceeded as 19 stations have been installed through cofinancing from the Southern African Science Service Centre for Climate Change and Adaptive Land Use SASSCAL 5 through cofinancing from the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa COMESA and 8 by the UNDPGEF Climate Change Adaptation project with the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock Thus the network of automatic weather stations has expanded from 2 to 32 This brings the current percentage of districts having automatic weather stations to 31 This will be increased further to 58 with the installation of 28 additional automatic weather stations by the CIEWS project in the second half of 2015 as the equipment is under procurement
2 This modernization of the observing network has enabled realtime observation of current weather conditions Timeliness of data transmission and exchange has been improved as the automatic weather stations provide data at 15minute intervals 24 hours per day Furthermore the accuracy of weather forecasts has been enhanced

The targets for 2015 are: 1. finalize climate change financing framework 2. Develop National Adaptation Plans framework 3. Develop Intended Nationally Determined Contributions (INDC) 4. Develop the implementation plan for the climate change policy

As of end of the year, the following have been achieved 1.Intended Nationally Determined Contributions completed. The INDC identifies Sustainable Forest Management, sustainable agriculture and renewable energy and energy efficiency as key sectors that will drive Zambia towards low carbon resilient development. 2. National Adaptation Plan framework developed. The NAP framework provides a framework for developing adaptation projects in Zambia an source of funding for this projects

description.narrative: a) Average cost of elections per registered voter during elections b) Percentage of registered voters voting in elections (Voter turnout)

comment.narrative: Based on next election to be held in 2016
N/A
2016 General Elections (entire process including nominations, results management) held under amended electoral laws in line with the New Constitution.

UNDP supported the Electoral Commission of Zambia in collaboration with the Ministry of Justice to review relevant legal frameworks and in turn aligned these to the new Constitution of Zambia (Amendment) Act No. 2 of 2016. Support included the drafting, enactment and implementation of the Electoral Commission of Zambia Act No. 25 of 2016 and the Electoral Process Act No. 35 of 2016. As a result, the ECZ on 9 July 2016 invoked one of its new powers under the new Electoral Commission Act (Sub-section 28-2) resulting in the suspension of all political campaigning in Lusaka and Namwala for 10 days after clashes, therefore expanding a balanced playing field and participation of political players. Further, the Local Government Election Tribunals were operationalized to handle local government petitions within 30 days through support rendered on the training of 54 Tribunal Members. This included magistrates, lawyers and court clerks.
ECZ supported to develop an implementation plan for recommendations from the 2016 General Elections
Strategic Plan (2016-2020) integrated with lessons learnt from 2016 General Elections and Referendum
